body_text.text: Karyotyping, a technique to visualize banded chromosomes under a light microscope, allows for the genomewide detection of chromosomal rearrangements with a resolution up to 5 Mb, roughly corresponding to the size of a single chromosome band.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: This technique led to the discovery of aneuploidies, such as Down's syndrome, caused by an additional chromosome 21, as well as large structural variants, including interchromosomal translocations.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: The introduction of targeted methods, such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA), enabled the detection of smaller rearrangements with a resolution up to 150 kb -100 bp in selected regions of the genome.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: More recently, the development of microarrays has enabled the detection of small aberrations on a genome-wide scale [1][2][3].
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: The use of genome-wide arrays in populations of healthy controls led to the discovery of copy number variation.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: Copy number variants are defined as deletions or duplications not detectable by conventional karyotyping, with a size of at least 1,000 bp [4].
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: Currently, this technique detects very local, small chromosomal rearrangements of only a few kb in addition to large copy number variants in a routine basis.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: Such small aberrations may affect only a single gene and, thus, create unique opportunities to study gene function.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: This report highlights some recent breakthroughs in genomic research made possible by the detection of such small abnormalities and looks ahead to how the increased resolution of arrays can further contribute to gene discovery.
body_text.section: Introduction: the detection of chromosomal abnormalities

body_text.text: Somewhat surprisingly, the percentage of our genome that can harbour copy number variants is still the subject of debate.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: The first large-scale microarray study utilising a 26 K tiling path bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) array platform estimated that 12% of the genome is subject to copy number variants [5].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: Because of the probe size of at least 100 kb, these platforms typically overestimate individual copy number variant size and, consequently, also the total copy number variant content in our genome.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: However, after studying more than 2,000 individuals on higher resolution arrays containing over 550,000 probes, Shaikh et al.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: [6] and Itsara et al.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: [7] concluded that 16-19.4% of the genome is subject to copy number variants.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: This higher proportion is mainly a consequence of the increase in sample size compared to the previous study, as the total copy number variant content was composed of many small and rare copy number variants.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: Consequently, it would be reasonable to expect that the estimation of 3.7% copy number variable content in the genome, which was obtained by analysing just 41 HapMap individuals on a NimbleGen array set containing~42 million oligonucleotide probesthe microarray platform with the highest possible resolution today, would increase to a similar high percentage if the study population was sufficiently large to catalogue rare variants [8].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: Copy number variants identified by major studies on healthy populations, such as the HapMap project, which is aimed at cataloguing normal genetic variation in man, are accessible through the Database of Genomic Variants (DGV).
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: This database currently holds 37 microarray studies, and is, thus, a rich catalogue of human variation in healthy individuals.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: According to the DGV statistics consulted in June 2012, about 50% of the human reference genome may be copy number variable in healthy individuals [4].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: At the moment, it is uncertain whether the cumulative variation present in the database correctly represents the copy number variant content in our genome or whether this is an overestimation.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: For instance, some samples, most notably the HapMap samples, have been analysed multiple times, sometimes with strikingly different outcomes in copy number variant content between different studies.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: Whatever the exact percentage is, it has been demonstrated that copy number variants are a primary source of human genetic variation [9].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: For a comparison, the 1,000 Genomes Project identified about 36.8 million single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), covering only 1.3% of the genome [10].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: Moreover, per generation locus-specific de novo mutation rates are 100 to 1,000 times higher for copy number variants than for SNPs, which further emphasizes the role of copy number variants in the evolution and variation of the human genome [10][11][12].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in the healthy population

body_text.text: In our hands, specific causative copy number variants were found in about 10-20% of patients with intellectual disability in routine microarray screening, which is in line with published data [13].
body_text.section: Copy number variants in disease

body_text.text: Because of this high diagnostic yield, microarray analysis is gradually replacing karyotyping as the routine diagnostic test for genetic abnormalities in many clinical laboratories.
body_text.section: Copy number variants in disease

body_text.text: When specific copy number variants cause consistent clinical manifestations across multiple patients, a microdeletion or microduplication syndrome can be defined.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: These syndromes can be divided into two groups: recurrent and non-recurrent microdeletion or microduplication syndromes, which differ in the clustering of the copy number variant breakpoints.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: So far, over 50 clinically recognizable microdeletion and microduplication syndromes associated with intellectual disability have been reported [13].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: Genomic disorders [14][15][16] are recurrent microdeletion and microduplication syndromes, characterized by copy number variants with an identical size and clustered breakpoints, explained by the presence of low copy repeats flanking the copy number variants.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: The local chromosomal architecture makes these regions prone to non-allelic homologous recombination (NAHR) [17], resulting in the deletion or duplication of the sequences in between the low copy repeats.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: The 17q21.31 microdeletion syndrome was one of the first defined genomic disorders identified through reverse phenotypics.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: It is characterized by mild to severe intellectual disability, hypotonia, friendly behaviour and specific facial dysmorphisms, as well as epilepsy, cardiac defects and urologic anomalies [18][19][20].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: The deletion that causes this phenotype spans 900 kb and contains six genes.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: Non-recurrent microdeletion and microduplication syndromes are characterized by copy number variants in the same chromosomal region with non-identical breakpoints.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: The associated copy number variants arise by means of different recombination-repair mechanisms, such as non homologous end joining (NHEJ), fork stalling and template switching (FoSTeS) and break induced replication (BIR), all based on the occurrence of microhomology at the breakpoints [17,21].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: Non-recurrent disorders are frequently located in chromosomal regions that contain repetitive sequences.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: Examples include the Miller-Dieker syndrome, characterized by type I lissencephaly, severe psychomotor delay, hypotonia, epilepsy, microcephaly, feeding problems and typical facial features.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: The causal deletions vary in size up to 2.5 Mb, but all share a 400 kb region containing nine genes at 17p13.3 [22,23].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements

body_text.text: The specific phenotypes associated with microdeletion or microduplication syndromes are commonly attributed to an alteration in expression of dosage-sensitive genes in the copy number variant region.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: However, for many microdeletion and microduplication syndromes, there is much debate on the exact contribution of specific genes to the clinical manifestation of the patient.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: The increased resolution of current array platforms has enabled the identification of atypical copy number variants affecting only part of the genomic region associated with the phenotype.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: By careful study of the clinical manifestations of patients with small copy number variants, the role of individual genes in the disease has been elucidated in some cases (illustrated in figure 1 A-C).
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: For instance, two patients presenting with the typical symptoms of the 17q21.31 microdeletion syndrome were identified with a much smaller deletion comprising only two out of the six genes typically deleted [24].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Mutation analysis of these two candidate genes, MAPT and KANSL1, was performed in patients with the clinical characteristics of this disorder but without the typical deletion.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Point mutations in the chromatin modifier gene KANSL1 were found in these patients, and it was concluded that the clinical characteristics of this genomic disorder can be caused by defects in this single gene [24,25].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Similarly, a long search to determine which of the genes deleted in the Prader-Willi syndrome are key contributors to the phenotype is nearly finished following the identification of a patient with a small copy number variant inside the Prader-Willi syndrome canonical region [26].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: The child manifested most of the major symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome and harboured an interstitial paternal deletion encompassing only the SNORD116 C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) cluster.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: In other cases, specific small copy number variants in the critical genomic region of microdeletion or microduplication syndromes can rule out the involvement of suspected candidate genes.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: We recently identified a pure hemizygous deletion of the CLIP2 gene, located within the Williams-Beuren syndrome canonical region [27].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: CLIP2, along with GTF2I and GTF2IRD1, were known as the key candidate genes for the characteristic cognitive and facial abnormalities associated with the Williams-Beuren syndrome.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: We could not demonstrate any abnormalities in two healthy siblings carrying the CLIP2 deletion and, thus, concluded that haploinsufficiency of this gene alone is not sufficient to cause any of the cognitive or facial features of this syndrome.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: In many non-recurrent microdeletion and microduplication syndromes, careful correlation of local chromosomal rearrangements to the clinical characteristics of the carriers has led to the identification of the disease gene within the candidate region.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Talkowski et al.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: [28] recently pinpointed the MBD5 gene as the single causal locus for the intellectual disability, epilepsy and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) associated with the 2q23.1 microdeletion syndrome.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: This correlation was deduced by comparing the molecular and phenotypic data of 65 patients for which MBD5 was the only affected gene in common.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Causative genes for several other genomic disorders have also been identified using the same approach, including MEF2C in the 5q14.3 microdeletion syndrome [29], SATB2 in the 2q33.1 microdeletion syndrome [30], HDAC4 in the brachydactyly mental retardation syndrome [31], SHANK3 in the Phelan-McDermid syndrome/22q13 deletion syndrome [32], and CREBBP in the Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome [33].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Although these examples illustrate the importance of very local rearrangements in the study of genomic disorders, it should be noted that not each contiguous gene syndrome is due to deficits in only a single gene.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Very small local rearrangements can also pinpoint a disease gene outside regions of microdeletion or microduplication syndromes.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: MYCN was identified as causative for the Feingold syndrome following the identification of copy number variants encompassing this gene in patients with the clinical characteristics of this syndrome [34].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: In a similar way, the FOXF1 gene was identified as causative for alveolar capillary dysplasia [35].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Other examples include two studies flagging NRXN3 and CMIP as putative autism genes following the identification of rare microdeletions, including these genes in autistic patients [36,37].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: More causative gene identifications lie ahead of us With the introduction of higher resolution arrays in routine diagnostics, we can expect an increasing number of very local chromosomal rearrangements to be identified.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: These small copy number variants detected in patients are submitted to databases, such as DECIPHER, ECARUCA and ISCA, along with phenotypic information [38-44]. A closer look at the data submitted, for instance to DECIPHER, suggests that many more causative gene identifications may lie ahead of us.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: In this database, currently containing publicly available data from 6,000 patients, about 80 de novo single gene aberrations are present, consisting of 55 deletions and 25 duplications.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Using the DAVID annotation tools [45], we found that 55% of these genes are expressed in the brain and 15% are involved in the functioning of the glutamate or N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-receptors (unpublished observations).
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Furthermore, genes involved in neurogenesis, differentiation and coding for developmental proteins are enriched in this set.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: These data clearly suggest a role for at least some of these small copy number variants in neurological disease.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: As some microdeletion or microduplication syndromes cannot be attributed to a single gene defect, careful study of the clinical presentation in relation to the affected gene(s) is necessary to decide whether the observed abnormality is causative for (part of ) the phenotype of the patient [46].
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Genotypic and phenotypic information stored in copy number variant databases are critical for the accurate interpretation of these results.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: However, the information in these databases should be used with caution as misannotated entries appear to be present.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: For example, two individuals included in the DGV carry a deletion of the ELN gene, causing supravalvar aortic stenosis.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: In addition, single gene deletions of the KANSL1 gene, causal for the 17q21.31 microdeletion syndrome, are present in this database.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: There are two possible explanations for this observation.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: First, these regions might be false positive results, as each microarray technology inherently yields a low amount of false positive results.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: Second, the variants may be bona fide but are not associated with the expected clinical phenotype in these individuals, either due to genetic background or to incomplete penetrance.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: In either case, the user should be aware of the associated phenotypes before filtering copy number variants against these databases.
body_text.section: Very local chromosomal rearrangements lead to the genetic dissection of microdeletion and microduplication syndromes and gene identification

body_text.text: As the resolution of the arrays in routine diagnostics continues to increase, it can be expected that more very local rearrangements will be found.
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: The interpretation of the clinical consequences of such copy number variants will remain challenging.
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: It is, therefore, important to integrate clinical information, functional annotation of affected genes, and published cases in interpretational workflows.
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: This report illustrates how small copy number variants that affect a single gene only led to the identification of disease genes inside or outside regions of known microdeletion or microduplication syndromes.
body_text.section: Future directions

body_text.text: Thanks to the introduction of high-resolution microarray analysis in routine diagnostics in many laboratories, many more small copy number variants will be detected, and we expect that many more exciting discoveries lie ahead of us.
